item.description:
The king's castle was attacked. The Dragodor Princess takes her prisoner. 
Players roll the dice on their turn and move to king's castle.
Who will be the first to overcome all obstacles and reach to castle to beat the Dragodor is the winner

Each player is an inventors who must be the first to patent three of his inventions. There is also consumers who goes around on a track schedule from store to store and pay money to its owners.

In his turn player rolls 2 dice, advances the number of spaces indicated and applies the effects of the square he stands:

 He may earns the royalties were deposited at least one patent
 He may buy or exchange different components to make a prototype or invention
 Move the consumer on the trail of stores and pay royalties to its possessor




etc.

Once its patents obtained nationally, you have to pay for these and go to the finish. Try to be the first at finish with 3 obtained patents to be the winner.

User summary

A Japanese small-press card game about building a baseball team and then performing a match. The first part of the game is about recruiting team mates of which there are 27 unique ones; which are available and in which order varies. Each player has an attack value, a defence value, some special effect, how fast they run, where they hit the ball etc. In the second part, players use the team mates and the training cards they've collected to play out the baseball match; which includes comparing the different numbers and special powers on the team individuals, and using some hand management to play the right card at the right time.

Translated box back blurb:
Players of all colours and with next to superhuman powers amass on the field, the devil curbs swirve through the air and the baseball bats burst out in fire!!!
This is a game based on such baseball comics.
With all the quirky rules of baseball, and using the characters' special powers, you can taste the charm of pitching and hitting in an easy way.

It's time to PLAY BALL!

The Battle of Leipzig, fought in 1813, is one of the largest conflicts ever and involved many countries / kingdoms fighting against each other. This included a coalition of Russia, Prussia and Austria committed to defeat France and its allies, forging a domination of Europe that would lead to the Nationalism of Germany. While historians have drawn a myriad of contrary opinions about who were the good guys and bad guys, the battle encircles the city of Leipzig with 500,000 man armies facing each other.

The sheer size of this conflict can truly test a designer’s skill when representing it at a battalion level. However, Leipzig is actually a series of smaller battles fought west, east, south and north of Leipzig as the Coalition armies concentrically move toward the City. La Bataille de Möckern 1813 is the battle north of Leipzig.

Möckern focuses on the raging struggle for this northern town which guards the passable roads to Leipzig moving south. As such, Napoleon entrusted the defense to Marshal Marmont and his VI Corps. In addition to veteran troops, Marmont has conscripts and sailors recently removed from the ports. Supporting Marmont is the III Cavalry Corps of de Casanova.

Coming down on this position is the Coalition’s Army of Silesia commanded by Marshal von Blücher. This army has a Prussian Corps, a Russian Corps and a Russian Cavalry Corps. The Prussians are fresh from several victories including holding Berlin. The Russians are somewhat smaller units given their casualties in 1812. However the Russians have a strong contingent of Cossacks and line cavalry.

The player will note immediately the differences in the Coalition formations and how each must be managed to achieve success. The French, Prussians and Russians Corps all operate a little differently injecting some real historical significance to the simulation and advancing the player’s skills as Corps Commanders.
Marmont held and lost the town of Möckern several times in this battle while the cavalry of Casanova held back the Russians. The fighting was intense, and continued into the dusk and evening hours.

Each 20 minute turn starts with a Command Phase for both sides followed by the French Player sequence and then by the Prussian Player sequence. The sequence includes movement, cavalry charges, fire and melee. During each, morale plays a decisive role. This is a great one player on one player game but will also accommodate two players on a side also.

The original rules have been updated but not expanded to any extent. The original designers of the La Bataille Series believe the Premier Rules facilitate / expedite the most accurate and competitive play. The new Premier Rules are an update of the original rules but make it easier to find specific topics and includes some user requested rules such as command control.

New rules for the players to consider are the effects of Elite Units, Landwehr skirmishing, Russian Dragoon’s abilities, improved towns, dusk combat, the loyalties of certain units, command structures and plundering. Besides the historical battle, four scenarios are included. These provide for a cavalry on cavalry only battle, inspired attacks by von Bluecher and the ability to jump into combat for the struggle of Moeckern itself. This scenario will end whenever a player reaches a threshold casualties and disintegration of order.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Bandits of the Crab Nebula is a game set in a chaotic universes where cunning rogues search for contraband to sell, all while avoiding the wrath of the Space Cops. Players pick from one of ten different ships, all with their own unique ability, and try and avoid asteroid belts, mine fields, and even police barricades.

Players control their ships speed, manage what is in their various hulls, install upgrades to better their chances of winning, and even play special cards to sabotage others. But they must also be careful to not be too greedy, because hidden in the deck where they find their items and cargo are special events that rarely end up good for anyone. These events can be as simple as one player discarding one piece of cargo, and as complex enough to warp everyone to a new location, have two players swap minds, or even put a ship swallowing black hole into play.

The aforementioned Space Cops are also a hassle, but also what sets the game apart from its peers. Players must manage how much cargo they are carrying and where they store it, because they might end up being accosted by the Space Cops when passing through a Police Barricade or when a rival player blows the whistle on them. If a Space Cop searches the Players ship and finds contraband, they must then deal with the consequences!

This is a simple dexterity game where players flip a wooden ball at the McMurtle Turtle target. If a player flips him over with a good shot, that player advances his/her colored wooden peg one space along the start/finish track. A spin at the beginning of the turn determines how many shots at the target each player gets. No two players can occupy the same space along the movement track at the same time, and special star spaces along the way advance a player's peg ahead to the first open space. The first player to reach FINISH wins.

Wizard Dodgeball is a sports game covering the annual all-star game of the Interplanar Wizard Dodgeball League (IWDL). Just like the dodgeball you know, the players who don't dodge the ball are eliminated; a caught ball eliminates the thrower, and the winner is the last team left on the court — but that's just the beginning as Wizard Dodgeball allows teams to throw spells in addition to balls. Boost your team, freeze your opponents, teleport balls back to your side, and watch out for fireballs!

In the game, players are dealt a team of five wizards each, and the turn order is determined by the order of the deal. Players then select spell cards based on how many spells their team can have. Each wizard has two action points that can be spent on moving, throwing balls, casting spells, or carrying out some combination of actions. Picking up or putting down balls is a free action.

Each wizard has a physical and magical range, and physical and magical attack and dodge bonuses. The outcome of throwing/casting and dodging is handled by high roll on d6s, with ties going to the defender.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Religious Charades in a way although you don't have to mime. Must be played in teams of at least two people.

In a turn, a player draws a card and tries to get his team-mates to name a Biblical character from his clues. The first team to get a pre-agreed number of characters correctly, wins.

The rulebook promises a Family Devotions variant but the rules were missing from my set so I do not know this variant at all.

A soccer (football) simulation from this publisher who only makes statistical sports games.

Teams are rated for attributes like Shooting, Defense, Assists (which is not a record kept in traditional football but must occur in serious indoor soccer) and so on. Dice are used to decide if a certain skill is successful or not. The most goals wins the match.

Includes two seasons worth of teams that play in the North American Indoor Soccer Leagues.

Statistical game, allowing you to replay Ice Hockey matches. As usual with this publisher, teams are rated for skills such as Shooting, Defense, Assists, Saves, and so on. Once an option has been chosen, dice are rolled to see if the chosen action succeeds or, if it fails, to see if the opposition gain control of the puck. Most goals wins.

My copy suggests that Gamecraft, another statistical sport game publisher, made this game first but I have never seen it. Usually with Valgames, Bob Valvano designs the game but in this case, I guess he didn't.

Theme: "In 1808 at Oak City, a mutiny in the prison ends with the escape of all prisoners. The authorities then distribute posters depicting the fugitives, promising appetizing values for each catch. Each player represents a group of armed cowboys who wants to get the opportunity to enrich easily, while working with the sheriff and his co-workers. But the prices set for each capture are not invariable and it will take as much force as diplomacy to pocket."

Wanted! The rewards is a tactic game of area control, where players must capture the most fugitives they can, for the highest price. Each player has 16 cards (cowboys) with a specific strenght (0 to 5) and special habilities. Each card is played to influence the meeples (fugitives) that borders it. When an area containing meeples is completly surrounded, the player with more strenght wins the current money for each of them (if there is a tie, a duel happens!). Besides surrounding areas containing fugitives, players must also make the better use of their card habilities to obtain the best rewards. This happens because the prices are variable. The player who uses best the "prices market" will take an important advantage, because it's preferable to capture less if the price is higher. Cards may be played face up and face down. For each card side players may choose do to the card hability or not. When playing a card face down, besides the bluff, you may move the "sheriff" of your color up to two intersections. This pawn has a strategic interest, because he strenghts all the player cards of his color by +1 (only the ones he touches). Some strategic combinations of cards can be made to prevent other players to gain a lot of money.

Besides the basic game players may choose to play it in the advanced mode, which includes a Horse which helps the player who controls it to move his sheriff further, while being stronger, and a Prison (for an ending score).

In June 2012 the game was finalist in the Plateau d'Or Boardgame Design Contest (Canada).
In April 2013 the game was finalist among 138 in Granollers Boardgame Design Contest (Spain).
In April 2013 the game won the «Coup de Coeur» prize in the NTPSLM Boardgame Design Contest (Canada) among 124 games.

item.description:
Small quiz game that tests your knowledge of Britain's second longest soap, Emmerdale. No board, just 54 question cards, with six questions per card.

In your turn, roll the die and the player on your left reads out the question to you that relates to the number thrown. There are six categories on each card. If you get the question right, you keep the card and you roll the die and you are asked the question indicated on the next card, and you keep going until you get an answer wrong. If you are wrong, the card goes back to the bottom of the stack and the turn passes to the player on your left.

The player with the most cards when the deck runs out, wins.

A solitaire game is also suggested. Turn over the cards one at a time. Roll the die and answer the question indicated. If you are right, place the card on your left and call cards won, the Winning pile. If you are wrong, place it on your right and call those the Duffer's pile. Keep going until all 54 cards are exhausted. Collect 28 or more cards in your Winning pile and you have won. If you have more than 27 cards in your Duffer's pile, you lose.

Hermann Köhl (1888 - 1938) was the first aviator to fly across the Atlantic from east to west, i.e. from Europe to North America (accomplished in 1927). This game celebrates that feat. The track is 50 spaces long, tracing Köhl's route, from Germany to North America and back home again.

The game is not very novel in the game-play. Roll a die and move along the track. Obey instructions when you land on a special square. Very nice illustrations illuminate these special points along the track.

First to get to the end, wins.

2 players are positioned on either side of the table and place the wooden cubes with pictures on 4 sides between them.

Object of the game is to get row of four identical pictures.

There are 3x3 grid game board and 2 types of game-pieces red cylinders and yellow cubes. Players draws a cards where are tasks how do position the game-pieces.

At the beginning of each round the board is empty.
Each player draws a card of his objective and in his turn player places or swaps the game-pieces.

The goal of the game, is to achieve the placement showed on the card, either during installation or by swapping two pieces later stage. The player gets a card as a point.

At the end of the game if the deck is exhausted, the player with the most cards is the winner.

Statistical cricket game from the inexhaustable Terry Goodchild, who has designed more sports games than you have had hot dinners.

This game rates every County Cricket side for two seasons, 1985 and 1986. Dice are used and checked against certain ratings of the teams. Very few dice rolls are needed to complete a match because this game was intended to be a game where you can play an entire season in an evening. I don't know how many games that would be, around 150 perhaps, so a routine sports simulation was not wanted.

Dice based Rugby game, The box folds out into the inside of a rugby stadium, and both players have an elastic band powered catapult they use to "throw" the five dice into the box.

The hope is that the five dice will form a combination of moves resulting in a try.

Most tries, wins

Nemo is captured by a diver. His friends decide to go on a long journey in search of him.

In this cooperation game children search together Nemo.
In his turn, player spins the wheel and move the game-piece
building a puzzle path.

The game ends when Nemo is found (the players have won) or when the puzzle is completed Darla (then the players have lost).

name.value: Le Monde de Nemo: La Grande Evasion

item.description:
Object of the game is to escape from the aquarium first.

In his turn player draws a card and play a card.
There are usual cards to move his fish to the next available slot
or special cards to exchange his hand, force opponent to discard one card etc.

First fish who has completed his journey to ocean is the winner

Rover Rummy consists of a deck of 51 cards, divided into dog "parts" - fronts, rears, bodies, heads, legs and tails. Each set of parts (except the tail) is divided into colors which denote the correctness of the body parts. Green being poor, then Yellow (fair), then Red (good), with Blue being the best (excellent). Each player is dealt 6 cards per hand. Play progresses by a simple "draw and discard" method.

The object of the game is to win the required amount of points to obtain a Championship on your "dog". A Championship is obtained by accumulating 15 "points" (based on the combined values of the colored body parts forming one "dog") over the span of several hands, and 2 major wins ( A major = a hand of 3, 4 or 5 points). The rules of winning a Championship in this game are the same pointwise, as winning a real Championship. The first player to lay down a complete "dog" wins a hand. The hand is counted by adding up the point value of each of the body parts, or in the case of a complete "red" or "blue" dog, the point value assigned to that dog.

1930's party game.

There are 5 large, cardboard horses. Each horse is attached to a length of string. Up to 5 players can play but more can be included if they just bet on the result. Each player with a horse stands about ten feet away from the agreed finish line. Their line of string is attached to something substantial, like a dining room table. At the cry "They're Off!", players jiggle their string and their horse should start to move to towards the finish line. It will get pretty frenetic but that adds to the fun. First owner to get their horse to the finishing line wins.

The card game Nox features ninety cards, thirty each in orange, green and blue. Each player starts each round of play with three cards in hand. On a turn, a player either:


 Plays one card in front of herself or another player to expand that player's kitty, or
 Plays that card on top of a matching-colored card in any player's kitty.


Any time that a player has two stacks topped with a card of the same number, those stacks are merged into a single stack. After playing, the player draws one card from the deck.

As soon as one player has six separate stacks in front of herself or all players have no cards left in hand, the round ends. Any player without stacks topped by cards of all three colors scores zero points for the round; all other players sum the numbers shown on the uppermost card of each stack they have. Rounds continue until at least one player has scored at least 150 points. In this case, the game ends and the player with the most points wins.

For a harsh variant, players can decide that only the player with the most points each round scores, while everyone else receives zero points. In this variant, the game ends once a player reaches 100 points.

item.description:
This is a long-waited sequel game of Struggle of Army Group Manstein.
The game starts just after the battle of Kursk in Summer 1943 and ends in March 1944.

The game uses the same engine as its predecessor. Each player selects his chits each turn, then draw chits one by one and activate part of the force designated by the chit.
The Soviet player must break the German defense line until the end of the game. The German player must keep the defense line until the end of the game.
The interesting new idea is "no retreat" order by Hitler. There are 6 cities which have no retreat order at the start. If German player lose one of them while it still has this order, the game immediately ends with Soviet sudden victory. So, German player must defend them or release the order by sacrificing their reinforcement.

Time scale: per turn
Unit scale: German divisions; Soviet corps
Counters: 252 1.3cm/0.51 inch
Map: 72 cm x 51 cm
Duration: August 1943 - March 1944 (8 turns)


Issue game of Game Journal #42

This is a game about dwarfs knocking each other into pits and collecting gold. Dwarfs are natural fighters, and this game naturally contains a lot of fighting. It also contains forest elves to kick.

Players take turns moving their dwarfs around the board and use item cards to trip up the other dwarfs. Depending on what game mode is in play GOLD could be waiting at the end of a race, ready to be dug up, or even in the hands of a GNOME IN A MECHANIZED POWER SUIT. It's up to the players to use their dwarfs special skills to out maneuver the competition.

Tessels is a trivia game about homonyms (words with different meanings)
The game consists f 50 cards, each with 3 hints on a homonym.

Players simultaniously try to find the right hymonym. If a player can find the word with only the first hint, he scores 3 points, after the second hint, he gets 2 points and after the 3rd one point.

The first hint is a sentence with the homonym replaced by TESSELS, for example. "While the perents went to a TESSELS, their children played with a TESSELS.

The second hint consists of synonyms for the two meanings (like "orb dance")

And the third hint is a sketch.

Promotional Canadian game, issued by the tyre supplier.

The board is a track, taking you from Halifax to Vancouver. As usual in these sort of games, if you land on a space with instructions, then you must follow those instructions, be they good or bad.

When you get to one space from winning, you must stop there. You cannot get to Home without rolling a double on the dice. This probably means that you will be there for a few turns which helps others to catch up and make the end of the game a little more exciting. First to Home (Vancouver), wins.

Each player has a map overlaid with squares. One player is the Smuggler, the other is a Coastguard. Players start at oppositer ends of the map. Movement is governed by dice. Both players fill in the squares on the path they have taken that throw. Filled-in squares cannot be used again by the player who filled them in.

The objective is to avoid interception or to intercept, depending on which side you are on.

name.value: Die Siedler von Catan: Baden-Württemberg Edition

item.description:
In 1952, three German states – Württemberg-Hohenzollern, Baden, and Württemberg-Baden – voted to merge into a single state, and for the sixtieth anniversary of that event, Kosmos and designer Klaus Teuber have released a special edition of Teuber's Settlers of Catan to celebrate.

Baden-Württemberg Catan is like other Catan games in that players roll dice to determine which areas on the game board produce resources that turn, trade resources with other players, and use resources to build settlements, cities, roads, and to purchase development cards. Settlements, cities, and roads earn their owners victory points (VPs), and the first player to have ten VPs wins.

Where Baden-Württemberg Catan differs from some Catan games – yet is similar to others, such as Catan Geographies: Germany – is that the game board features the southwestern state of Baden-Württemberg (with fixed resource numbers on the locations) and players can build key landmarks within the state, such as the Stuttgarter Fernsehturm or Heidelberg Castle.

Didactic board game played on a board with the features and markings of hockey on grass, with two smart charts for each team,one dice, 8 sided role and only one piece to move on the board.This feature makes the game very agile and entertaining.
Each team, consisting of one or two people, must follow in the smart chart the current situation of the game according to what the 8-sided dice throw and go placing the piece on the board in the place that corresponds with a indicating the smart chart in use.
The objetc of the game is to lead the team through the smart charts and score a goal.

Objective: be the first entering field 80
 - moving by turn -
simple 'Roll & Move' game; stepping on a marked space follow instructions.
remarks:
published during 1920's
equipped with pewter figures ~ 2 inch tall

This is a derby racing game based on the recuring "Slime Races" in the Dragon Quest video game series.

This game uses cards to move the various-colored Slimes around the racetrack. Most cards involve moving a specific Slime a specific number of spaces, but several special cards apply to Slimes in certain race positions (e.g. The Slime in first place may double the distance between it and the Slime in second). Some Slimes have a better set of movement cards than others, and therefore receive lower odds on the betting chart.
Players each get a hand of 7 cards. Depending on what cards a player has, they can form a strategy for which Slimes they think they can push into first and second place at the finish line. The players bet on which Slimes they think will win. Players then take turns playing cards to move the Slimes until there is a first and second place winner. Players tally up their score and advance their score marker. First player to reach 50 points wins the game.

The rulebook is in Japanese, but there are many illustrations, so it is possible to figure out the rules.

Wartiles is a fantasy tile laying game, taking inspiration mainly from Warhammer Fantasy Battle and other fantasy wargames.

Each player start with an army general and must defeat its opponent's general. To do so, each player has access to army tiles that are layed on the board. In some way, it might look as dominoes.

Terrains and powerful spells come in play to add some twists.

				
					=====================================================

Wartiles est un jeu de combat fantasy dans lequel les unités du jeu sont représentées par des tuiles. Ce jeu tire son inspiration principalement de Warhammer Fantasy Battle mais aussi de plusieurs autres jeux dans le même style.

Chaque joueur commence avec une tuile général et le but du jeu est de réussir à vaincre le général des autres adversaires.Des tuiles représentant des unités sont placées sur le plateau et le tout pourrait s'apparenter à une partie de domino, spécialement dans l'apparence et la manière de placer les tuiles en jeu.

Des terrains et de puissants sorts viennent pimenter la partie.

The year is 1941. Within eight months, the United States will join in the war raging in Europe and brewing in the Pacific. However for the moment, the lives of most Americans continue in relative peace...unless you live in the City by the Bay.

In San Francisco crimes, mysteries, and good old-fashioned murder present unique challenges to detectives and residents alike – especially if you happen to be a detective investigating a dirty backroom deal inside a neon lit nightclub, or a future criminal plotting against a spouse under a flickering streetlamp. It is up to you, the players, to create the story.

Ace Detective – which features color and black/white artwork from the grand masters of detective pulp Black Mask Magazine – is a noir storytelling card game that rewards imagination and the turn of a good tale. Play your cards right, tell your story, and be rewarded with the plot points needed to place clues on the suspects of the crime. But be careful as everyone in this gritty city is competing to tell his or her own story...

...to become the true ace detective.

item.description:
The language of creation was stolen and given to Eve, and with it the power to alter reality. Inheritors of this forbidden knowledge have walked amongst us for millennia, scrabbling for greater power, controlling mankind, seeking god-hood, and they are known as Magi.

Serpent's Tongue is a spell-casting simulation game, with a standalone core set that is expandable with Inscription Packs. In the game, players become Magi by building their Hardbound Spell Codex with Incantations and casting them using an actual functioning language, whether in competitive battles or cooperative adventures.

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
“IN GREAT DEEDS SOMETHING ABIDES. ON GREAT FIELDS SOMETHING STAYS." —Joshua Chamberlain

It's July 1863 and the Army of the Potomac is holding on. Yesterday the Johnnies hit hard and the line held. Today you are the leftmost flank of the army and must not give an inch of ground.
Though dulled by the morning mist, the shrill sound of a Rebel Yell is unmistakable. The Johnnies are on the move again.

Will you hold?

Rifles & Rebels is a unit based game where units are composed of 5 to 10 figures. In Rifles & Rebels you can choose from two sides and two arms with a total of four forces. You can be:

• Union Infantry
• Confederate Infantry
• Union Cavalry
• Confederate Cavalry
Whichever you choose you must lead one or more units of men through the war, the American Civil War, fighting when needed because it's all about victory and glory, and in some cases, just survival!
The cannon are booming, the troops mustering, and the fight is coming to you. Welcome to …

RIFLES & REBELS
Rifles & Rebels uses a floating scale which allows you to count each unit as a platoon, company, or battalion. This allows you to fight large battles as well as smaller actions.
Rifles & Rebels and Muskets & Mohawks share similar mechanics with changes made to reflect the different periods.

(From the producers website)

name.value: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs Bagatelle
Walt Disney's Uncle Remus Game Zip

item.description:
A bagatelle board resembles a light, flat board with nails (pins!) in it and short raised sides to keep the ball on the playfield during play. Each ball is launched from some sort of spring-loaded 'shooter' or cue, to the top of the board, where it then rolls towards the player, bouncing off the pins or landing in any of several scoring pockets. These scoring pockets can be depressions in the playfield, nails arranged in a U-shape, or both. They are marked with various score values, with the higher values usually protected by more pins or tougher paths to reach them. By "shooting" the ball harder or softer, the player can try to control where the ball drops.

A spring-loaded shooter is normally in the bottom right corner of the board. A ball is placed before the shooter mechanism. The shooter devise is pulled back and let go, with the aim to fire the ball up to the rounded end of the board and then to bounce around the nails or pins and, hopefully, land in a scoring area. A cue shooter is just a wooden object, rather like a miniature version of a Billiards cue. To launch a ball, the player merely shoots it by hitting the back of the ball with the cue thus sending it to the top of the board.

Note that it is possible for a ball not to score at all. This usually means that the ball reached the bottom of the board without settling into a scoring pocket.

Typically, a player might get 3 or more balls and a note of the total score achieved is taken. The first to reach a pre-agreed number of points, wins.

Bagatelle sets can be made of wood, metal or plastic and they can be of any size (but it must be able to stand on an average table). They are often linked to a theme, really as an excuse to feature related graphics. The game is a direct ancestor of modern Pinball machines.

link.value: The Legend of King Arthur and the Knights of the Round Table
Eelco Martinus ten Harmsen van der Beek

item.description:
Priest of Apollo, Athena, Demeter, Poseidon or Zeus, 3-5 players try to make their worship the one who will dominate the whole of Greece. As you gather up YOur followers, build monumental temples, free the cities of mythological monsters, use your political weapons for your own benefit.

The game consists three phases:

 Action Phase
 Agora Phase
 Stage season




In his turn in first phase player places his followers to build temples, gather resources and hunt monsters to get more followers.

Also it is possible to convert opponents' cities, or even paralyze them by sending Your monsters to attack them.

In Agora Phase player deifies his heroes, who offer more improved actions for the action phase

Finally the season phase is a phase of replacement.

Player must meet at least 10 worshipers ( or have Three shrines before the end of the game to be the winner of the game.

Valkyrie is a game of checkers with 2 boards. One is Midgard (Earth), the other Asgard (heaven). When the game starts, each player has three gods and a Valkyrie on first board 9 troops (human or monsters) on the second board.

Player wins the battle if he eliminate 3 opponent's gods or has last man standing on the second board.

In his turn player has 2 actions/movements according to the following rules:

 troops move one square in the 8 directions
 the gods move one square orthogonally and never back
 the Valkyries move freely on the set except the last line.




If the move ends on square with an opponent the battle begins.

The value of a pawn in combat is equal to the value of the piece (5 for the gods, 1 to 3 for the troops).

The Valkyries may move a troop from one world to another if it stands one of the adjacent square.

German game celebrating Germany's fame, as they were once the leading airship manufacturer in the world.

The game is a simple roll and move game, taking your Zeppelin across Europe and visiting the major cities. Obey instructions if you land on special spaces. First to the end of the track, wins.

Undoubtedly seen as an educational game, teaching children about their neighbouring countries as well as their aeronautical history.

name.value: Modern Armor: Miniatures Rules for AFV's of the Contemporary Era

item.description:
Modern Armor is a set of miniatures rules "based on U.S. Army doctrine and the combat experiences of the author." The information is based on unclassified 1976-77 data. 
 The game is set up to be used with 25mm or 1/76 scale vehicles, but 1/285 scale micro-mini tanks are just as easily accommodated with minor adjustments.
 The game can use simultaneous movement with written orders, or a move/countermove system.
 In addition to Armor, rules include Indirect Fire, Small-Arms Fire, Infantry, Morale, Smoke, Amphibious Capabilities, Repair and Recovery of Vehicles, Airborne Operations, Armed Helicopters, and Air Strikes.

Take on the role of one of the Three Little Pigs as you try to build a house strong enough before the Big Bad Wolf arrives to blow it down and eat you. Move around the board collecting straw, sticks, and/or bricks and then bring them back to your building site to build your house before the big bad wolf arrives. Will you risk travelling further to get to the brick pile, or build a house of straw quickly and then sit back and relax counting on luck to save you when the big bad wolf comes calling.

Watch out, your brother pigs can steal what you’ve collected before you get it back to your house or speed up the wolf’s approach. The pigs whose houses still stand at the end of the game are the winners.

Extra points are awarded for being lazy, but they only matter if your house can survive the coming wolf.

Do you want to take your chances by building a house of straw?

Do you have the time to gather the bricks for your house before the wolf arrives?

Are your brother pigs going to steal your bricks before you can get them back to your house?

Move fast and be smart or it won't matter how much hair you have on your chinny chin chin.

Horse racing game that takes its game-play from the traditional British card game of Racing Aces.

The cards are shuffled and a number are taken out of the deck and revealed to the players. In the race, cards will be revealed and the horse in that racing colours will advance one space. This is done for each card revealed until one horse crosses the finish line.

It will be seen that some horses will have less cards in the pack than others. This is because when you take out the cards before the race begins, those cards are no longer in the pack, so the horses affected have less cards available and thus have less chance of winning. The odds for them to win will be higher than the odds om horses with, for example, all their cards still in the deck.

Players bet on each race and after a pre-agreed number of races, the player with most money, wins.

John Rickman, British television's eccentric horse racing expert, pictured on the box.

Game that tries to encourage people into the hobby of Genealogy, ancestor hunting you might say.

Generations is a board game with playing method which uses logic reasoning (in this regard, very similar to Cluedo) to solve a mystery of family history. Players search 7 regions of the United States for their make-believe ancestors, U.S. birthplaces, careers and lifestyles.

The first player to complete a family history (i.e. work out which facts are hidden, by eliminating facts that have been revealed to that player), wins.

Several game options ensure that play never becomes boring and that different levels of skill can be achieved. Variations include:
Logic Reasoning: Adapt for the time you have and the playing skill levels by varying the number of search categories. .
Storytelling: At the end of the game, the winner can make up a story about the discovered ancestor's life using "facts" found during play. This variation develops imagination and communication skills.
True Family History: Introduce players to real family stories as they "travel" regions of the United States asking questions about their pretend ancestors, where they were born, how they may have lived and how they earned their living.

Contents;
playing instructions (for home and classroom)
game board
moving pieces
dice
cards
lifestyle tokens
career tokens
ancestor worksheets
realistic family tree charts

You are the Spymaster of a team of agents -- Your Mission is to penetrate the Control Centre and seize the Master Modules hidden there. BUT... Counter intelligence sources have discovered that a rival power has despatched a team of ruthless Agents to oppose you.
You must direct your team to the control Centre via an international network of safe houses. En route, you must eliminate the opposition whilst avoiding their murderous attempts on your agents.

Essentially a game where you plot movement on your board and try to work out where the enemy is on his board. Lots of guessing and bluffing needed. The winner is the first player to capture any one piece of the five Master Module pieces. You can also win if you are the lone survivor.

A triumph of design, nothing is wasted. The game comes in a leatherette wallet, the pieces are magnetic and stick to the player boards and the rules are on the back of these boards. The boards and components are suitably dark and sinister for a game about espionage.

Contents
2 Dossiers
36 Spy Counters
6 Target Counters
5 Master Modules

Statistical tennis game, espec ially designed to get a result quickly, thus making it possible to play an event in one evening. Over 200 players are rated.

Verious statistics are provided, like ability, ranking, serving, etc., and a die is used to get a specific result for an action you have just attempted.

From the back of the box:

Love Sick is an quick and fun card game about venereal diseases (STDs) – and how to avoid them. .

In the game the players try to avoid a pile of disease cards - called ”the wad” - which passes around the table. If you have the right card or a condom, you can pass it on – otherwise you’ll get infected. The winner is the player with the fewest disease cards at the end of the game.

LoveSick is designed for use when teaching teenagers about sex and sexual health and it shows in an entertaining and alternative way how condoms can protect you from STDs. It’s full of important knowledge about STDs and sexuality, and it can be used both as a break from class teaching or as a foundation for talking about sex.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: Australian Chess variant played on a chequered board in the shape of a cross. Each side has 16 pieces but four pawns are larger than the other four. This designates them as either King's pawns or Queen's pawns. Bishops only play on black squares. Almost all other rules are standard chess rules and objectives.

Statistical cricket game with over 120 players rated in areas like batting, bowling and fielding. When this was designed, One Day International matches would last for 50 overs to be bowled by both sides. There is a certain hit and hope element when compared to full Test Matches. In 50 overs you don't have time to build an innings. So a player's One Day rating will be very different to a player's Test Match rating. This designer designed games for both codes of cricket.

Play is straightforward. A player metaphorically bowls a ball which has to be checked with dice against his rating, to see the outcome. Then a batsman rolls dice, against his batting ability, to see if he has hit it. Chances of 'Outs' could be decided by a briiliant delivery, or a mis-timed hit or a fantastic bit of fielding.

Two games in one box, the only link being that they are both designed to help 7 to 11 year-olds with their maths.

Ski Race is a dice game with four special dice that have very unusual number spreads on them. Children are encouraged to do simple maths with the numbers rolled and thus advance in the Ski Race.

Go For Goal is a football related game for 2 players only. Each player has a hand of cards and must use them (with some simple mathematics) to move the ball around the pich.

The publisher is a major name when it comes to publishing books for budding Hi-Tech students.

In Safari School you have to give the animals the right characteristics before your opponents.

Choose between 22 characteristics such as "Got wings" and "Eats plants". The first player who reach 15 points wins.

Other variations are possible depending on the number of players.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
"Goblin-Prügelparty" (Goblin-Beatingparty) is a Fantasy-cardgame in which two players take control of Goblins, kobolds and little devils, who enjoy beating up each other, after they have been summoned by a wizard who was not powerful enough to take control of them.
Players start with 3 cards on their hands and have to decide which cards to play for themselves and which to play for the opponent. Playing cards for the opponent may seem odd, but it is the only way to gain new cards. And since 11 cards in one of the card-rows end the game, you will need some more cards than the 3 you start with if you don't want the game to end early.
Nearly every single one of the 30 cards contains a unique effect, but while some of these effects are executed immediately, others wait for the end of the game before beeing executed. And you can't be completely sure whether they will be in the same position on the same side at that moment.
When the end is declared and the last effects have been executed, it is time to count the strenght and see who has collected the stronger - or more effective - little horde.

"B4U: Hipster Battle Game" is a simple 3-5 player card game where you try to play a card that has the highest "Irony" value out of your hand, or "Six Pack" as I like to refer to it. It's not as easy as all that though, because someone could play an event card that will completely throw the rules of that round a curve, making it anyone's game! This is a quick, and easy to learn and had a little snark to it as well. All you need to know how to do to play B4U is some simple math, and that's it.

How to play?

Gameplay is easy. As a round begins, you place two card facedown on the table. One in front of you, and one to your right. The card in front of you (which can either be a Irony card, or an Event card) will always come into play each round, but the one on the right (always an Irony card) may or may not.

After all necessary cards are placed into play, the card in front of everyone is turned over and exposed. In the simplest version of a round, the card played with the highest Irony value wins that round. If someone has played an Event card in the front position, then the round gets skewed in some fashion (explained on the card). Such things that could happen are the player with the lowest value wins, or you use the Irony value of both cards, etc.

When an event card is played, that is when the card to your right will be turned over. Some event cards also require you to play a third card onto the table.

After a winner for the round is determined, the round is over, and everyone puts any non-displayed cards back into their Six Pack, and draw back up to 6 cards if the Six Pack is not complete.

First player to win 7 rounds is the winner!

Players form two teams and each team chooses speaker.
The two speakers are placed side by side and they draws a card. There are words on the cards and speakers must explain it to players with the charades preferably more accessible to their own team.

The first team that sets the correct answer scores one point.

The game length is established before the game (10 points or 15 minutes). Winner is the team with the most points.

The Object of the game is to achieve an alignment of three pieces of Your color before opponent by making simultaneous displacements.

The pawns are placed on the central board and each player chooses number of movements and destination with his dice on his board. The results are revealed simultaneously.
- If a piece lands on a space occupied, it is placed on top.
- A stack of n pieces can move from 1 to n squares.

A player wins if he makes a row of 3 pawns or if he removes his opponent's pawns

Game description from the publisher:

Conjudingo includes three easy, fun games to help students from Grade 1 to Grade 4 work on the present, future and past tenses of French verbs. The various animals on the cards will help you check if you have found the correct combination.

By playing cards on the table each player tries to connect a maximum of lamas and his gang of lama-girls and form the biggest gang at the end of the game. 
Each player has one lama as a secret ally to add all this kind of lamas to his final score.

In his turn player draws a card from the deck or from the discard stack. Then he places one card on the table adjacent to any other card.
Also player may do 1 of the 4 available actions: exchange the card, scream, spit or move.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
New version of the game Shabadabada but here are more about songs from movies that are played.

Shabadabada Cinoche is a game that caters specifically to cinema lovers who have a solid understanding of classic films.

Two teams compete using predetermined words.

As soon as a player sings part of a song which contains the current word, the other team must find another song containing the word. As soon as a team fails, the other one wins the card.

Shabadabada promotional version made in Occitan.

Two teams compete using predetermined words.

As soon as a player sings part of a song which contains the current word, the other team must find another song containing the word. As soon as a team fails, the other one wins the card.

Add a colored tile each turn, trying to join the largest connected areas to maximize your score. Connect with all three colors for the most points. This game teaches pattern recognition and problem solving. With hundreds of combinations, there are infinite strategies to win!

Each turn, you connect one of your Game Tiles side to side to 1 or more Game Tiles in the middle of the table. The colors of the just-placed tile must match all adjacent tiles. Also, the corners of the Game Tiles must line up completely; that is to say that tiles may not overhang and the corners must match too.

Receive points for each game tile in the color chain that your tile connects to, but not including the tile you are adding.

Game description from the publisher:

Zahia as sports minister? Igor and Grichka for culture? Karl in the foreign office? Geneviève as home secretary?

Now you are head of state and must form a government made up solely of the right people. Make the right decisions as there are 42 candidates and you have to choose the most competent for each of the six ministries. Your goal is to make your popularity increase faster than that of the other players.

Si J'étais Président... (If I Were President...) is a simple, fun game with six game modes posing various types of challenges: shuffling cabinets, cracking the whip, enduring hung parliaments, etc. Let loose with your choices and the whole country will soon be head over heels in love with you!

name.value: Astronomie: Lernspiel für Jung und Alt

item.description: This is a small trivia game belonging to the series Wissen-Spielen-Lernen. It contains 98 cards, with questions about the universe. When you answer the questions you can get plus or minus points.

link.value: Komet Lernspiele für Jung und Alt

item.description:
Kites are a fun way to spend an afternoon in the park– if only the wind wouldn’t keep tangling up the strings! Race against the other players each round to be the first to figure out who is holding the kite shown on the die roll. This is a great way for kids to practice holding attention and mentally tracing a route in their heads.

First, the players roll the die. This determines the color that is being tracked this turn. At the same time, all players should mentally follow the string from the kite down to figure out which character is holding the other end of the string. Players must not use their fingers, just follow the string's path in their heads.

Once someone thinks they have the right answer, yell "STOP!" and grab the matching Solution Tile. Everyone checks together to see if this is the correct solution. Collect a Pinwheel for a correct answer, but lose a Pinwheel if you're wrong!

If you roll yellow and the yellow balloon is showing near the characters, players have to grab the Yellow Balloon Solution Tile instead of tracing the yellow kite's string. Similarly, if you roll orange and Squawk the parrot is showing near the kites, players have to grab the Squawk Solution Tile instead of tracing the orange kite's string. You lose a Pinwheel if you grab another Solution Tile when you should have chosen Squawk or the balloon!

The game comes with double-sided Character and Kite boards, and 2 double-sided and reversible String Boards to keep players guessing.

WHAT THEY'LL LEARN: Mental Mapping, Color Recognition, Quick Thinking

The sleeping dragon is protecting her stash of golden eggs, and she won’t be pleased to wake and find there are lizards sharing space in her warm nest. Help the lizards escape without breaking any of her precious eggs. It takes a careful hand to remove the lizards!

The Sleeping Dragon molded piece is placed in the center of the table, with 29 Lizards and 15 Golden Eggs placed on top of it. On your turn, use your Pinchers to try to remove once of the Lizards from the dragon:

- If you are successful without anything falling off the dragon, place the Lizard in front of you. Well done! You also get to keep any other Lizards that are attached!
 - If anything falls off the dragon, your turn ends immediately, but you can keep any Lizard already in your Pinchers (and any other Lizards attached to it). Any Lizards that fall off are placed in the box, and any Golden Eggs that fall are placed in front of you!

When all Lizards are removed from the dragon, the game ends. For each Golden Egg in front of you, you must return a Lizard! After accounting for all Golden Eggs, the player with the most Lizards wins.

WHAT THEY'LL LEARN: Visual Mapping & Analysis, Eye-Hand Coordination, Concentration

"A family game for all ages compliments of Roadrunner Pharmacy. Weave your way through Roadrunner Pak to reach the vacation that is waiting to start,"

Six colored pawns representing dogs and cats move around a path on the board using a spinner to determine how many squares to move. Not unlike Candyland - for pets.

In City of Iron, 2-4 players compete to build up a small nation in a world of machines, magic, and money. Become the leader of one of four rival nations: the industrious humans, the toad engineers, the scholarly Cresarians, or the clever hogmen. Produce goods like machine parts and bottled demons to gain wealth, or research steam-age technology and recruit mercenaries to control the continent. If you want to establish new cities, you’ll build schooners or airships to reach faraway lands and flying islands. Your cities have limited capacity, so you’ll have to decide what to keep and what to demolish when building advanced structures. The future of a nation is in your hands. Build unbreakable foundations for an empire or disappear into the dusty pages of history.


 Build a civilization in a Steampunk setting
 Customize two decks of cards in a unique twist on deck-building
 Choose your path- build a powerful economy or conquer everything in sight
 Includes hundreds of lavishly-illustrated cards, an extra-large board, land boards, coin tokens, and more

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

link.value: City of Iron: Clockwork Fortress and Cave Market Promo
City of Iron: Experts and Engines

item.description:
Mille Bornes with the game board included for viewing obstacles and how fast players advance.

Players compete to drive 1000 km, dealing with hazards along the way. Draw a card to your hand, play or discard. You must lay a green traffic light to start, play cards showing mileage, dump hazards (flat tire, speed limit) on the other players, remedy hazards (spare tire, end of limit) from yourself, play safety cards (puncture proof), and try to be the first to clock up the distance.

Game description from the publisher:

Now fans can experience Wonderland in a way no one has ever experienced before as the comic book series Wonderland from Joe Brusha, Ralph Tedesco, and Raven Gregory comes to life in this exciting, strategy filled game. Experience a vibrant, twisted world, full of surprises! Players can choose to play as one of their favorite characters including Calie, the Mad Hatter, Brandon, the Queen of Hearts, the White Knight and a number of others.
 The board game Wonderland features two separate realms: Earth and Wonderland. The realms are artfully depicted on the double-sided board and switching between them adds a unique twist and an added level of complexity to the game that few other board games offer. Players compete against each other, each player trying to complete specific goals while the other players try to foil their attempts at progressing.

It's a game of statistical professional volleyball

The game recreates an entire volleyball match. Each action is divided in serve, reception, set, spike and so on based on individual and team statistics.

The entire game is driven by 102 FAC (Fast Action Cards).

Current set available: 
Serie A1 Italy 2010-2011
Olympic Games London 2012
Olympic Games Rio 2016
NCAA USA 2014

The game is free to print and play. In English

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Guns of Galicia uses the same core rules as Guns of August (GoA) to simulate Corp-level fighting on the Eastern Front in WWI. Game mechanisms compensate for players' 20/20 hindsight to encourage historically accurate play that makes "sense" in game terms while avoiding a "straight jacket" of special rules to enforce irrational play. Players maneuver corps and divisions through 9-mile wide hexagons in turns that span three days each. Chit pull activation along with modest movement point allowances generates a highly interactive game. Scenarios included are the 1914 Galicia campaign, 1915 Tarnow campaign, and 1916 Brusilov campaign.

name.value: Mystery Party: Meurtre sur le Nil

item.description:
Mystery Party: Meurtre sur le Nil is the first title in Cocktail Games' "Mystery Party" collection of games in which players take on the role of different characters and try to determine which among them has committed the crime they are now investigating.

Meurtre sur le Nil takes place in April 1937 on board the ship Le Sobek, during a cruise down the Nile. Roger Hastings’ lifeless body has just been found in his cabin with a bullet in his skull. As soon as the corpse is discovered, Le Sobek heads towards Assouan where the local police will take over the investigation. In the meantime the eight suspects are gathered in Le Sobek’s restaurant trying to make sense of the "murder on the Nile"...

The Tweegles are monsters from another galaxy, come to invade the Earth. Unfortunately for them, once they hit the ground, nothing is on their scale. They are frightening and huge monsters on their own planet, but are only as big as mice on earth. They land in an everyday house, full of traps for them: electrical sockets, children with scissors and stamps, insects and cleaning products...

Twenty-five action cards – each showing a tweegle that has been hit by one of the "traps" – are laid face-up on the table at the start of Tweegles, while the twenty-five tweegle cards are shuffled and set aside. Everyone plays at the same time. One tweegle card is revealed from the deck, with the card showing one of five tweegle types and one of five possible actions, symbolized by scissors, a mosquito, an electrical socket, a stamp and spray bottle.

Everyone searches for the action card that "completes the story" begun with the first card. If a tweegle card shows scissors, for example, you need to find the cut-up tweegle among the face-up action cards. To claim the card, however, you need to perform the appropriate gesture: slapping the card if a mosquito is involved, hammering it with your fist if the tweegle was stamped, and so on. The first player to do this claims the tweegle card, while the action card remains on the table.

Whoever claims the most cards wins!

"Being a game of genteel warfare for two players desirous of campaigning in the manner of the 18th century."

Cockpit of Europe was published as an article in issue No. 49 of Miniatures Wargames magazine in May of 1987. Despite its source this is not a set of miniatures rules, but a paper-and-pencil game of conducting campaigns and sieges in the late 17th and early 18th centuries. It allows two players without a referee to re-create the "limited" or "scientfic" wars of the period dominated by methodical sieges and maneuvering armies against the enemy's line of communication instead of pitched battles. While not detailed, it is rich in historical flavor, not in the minutiae of weapons and tactics but the general's big picture of moving armies within the constraints of supply and time.

Games consiste of several campaign seasons of twenty weeks. Armies must return to winter quarters each year, so only fortresses captured will be retained from season to season. Collecting intelligence is key, or you won't know if your siege train can reach the enemy and create a practicable breach before their supplies run out, or winter sends you home.

This is the warfare of Marlborough and Vauban!

name.value: All Star Wrestling Power Slam VCR Wrestling Game

item.description:
Players watch clips of wrestling matches from the old AWA league attempting to play a card that matches the move about to happen (there's a 3 second delay to allow players to choose which card to play)

A correct answer will allow that player to move his marker 2 spaces to the 'pin' space on the game board. If the card played has 'go for the pin', then if that player gets the next 2 card plays correct, they win. Game can also end when someone moves their marker to the pawn space

From the publisher:

Pro Stadium Soccer replicates a professional soccer championship with each player managing a team vying for the title. Who will be able to sign the over-priced but highly talented striker? Should you raise your bid for a promising young defender? Will one of your opponents try to snatch away your star goalkeeper on the eve of a crucial match?

Pro Stadium Soccer lets you control your team's destiny: opt for a lightning attack or develop an ironclad defense; choose stability and balance or spend wildly and make impulsive decision. Pro stadium soccer offers the ideal opportunity to experience the pressures of managing a real like soccer club. Naturally, the road to the championship is littered with obstacles: injuries, red cards, and heartbreaking defeats may stand in your team's way.

At the end of the day, all that matters is becoming Pro Stadium Champion.

This small sized edition of Pictionary plays similar to the original, but the drawing is not timed as there is no timer included. As wit traditional Picionary, players are drawing a picture based on a word from a card and trying to get their team-mates to guess the word in order to score points or advance.

name.value: Martial Art Love Affair High School

item.description:
User summary

A small-press amateur Japanese game; "Martial Art Love Affair High School" is a humouristic card game where the goal is to collect a certain combination of cards, that together form a four-panel cartoon. One card at a time is put out, and players select if they want it or not. If several players want the card, they have to fight for it; fights being decided by dice rolling and some tactical card position choices.
When one player has completed hit set, the round ends and points are calculated. Game plays for five rounds.

User summary

A Japanese 2-player combat card game. Each player chooses two of nine witches, that all have their unique combination of spells, and take turns drawing cards from a deck consisting of 6 types of mana. Players build up their mana pools by playing "towers" (stacks) of cards from their hands, and can then activate these towers to unleash the spells of one or both of their witches.
Damage is represented by drawing cards from the mana deck; if two identical cards are drawn the pair dies.

Translated box blurb
When the stars align in the sky,
the witches prepare
for a battle of life and death

In Master Trader players produce one or more unique resources and these are traded for the other players' in order to form a set according to a specific privilege a player has and this combination gives them a specific reward in the shape of gold coins, advanced resources or Victory Points (VP).

The goal of the game is a race to become the first player with a specific amount of VP.

There are many unique privileges arranged in three levels:
In Level 1, players trade 3 different basic resources for 1 gold coin.
In Level 2, players trade 2 different basic resources for 1 advanced resource.
In Level 3, players trade specific combinations of advanced resources and/or gold coins for VP and/or gold coins.

All privileges must be purchased with gold coins.

The game plays over an unlimited amount of rounds, each round consisting of 3 phases. Phases 1 (Free Trade) and 2 (Resource Conversion) are concurrent (no player turns). Phase 3 (Buy Privilege) occurs in a particular order that gives preference to the weaker players at the time.

The entire game is based on a closed economy with limited resources.

A promotional pack of cards, with the four normal suits being replaced by Bottles, Arks, Humphreys and Jokes.

The rules to various games are given:
Bottle Up!
Happy Humphreys (this is a slight variant of Happy Familes)
Hello Humphrey (better known as Pairs)
Humphrey Patience
Humphrey Overboard

There are 52 cards plus a Joker. Each suit bears a symbol to match its name, but the 13th card in each suit is always a crown. The game was mailed to interested customers in a plain white box except for one side that invites the owner to enter his or her name.

Each card also bears the normal traditional suit and number so that the cards could be used to any other card game that you like.

In a fantasy world dominated by goblins, when the blood moon rises in the sky, a new war begins and new warlords raise their armies.

GOSU 2: Tactics plays like a hybrid of Race for the Galaxy and Magic: The Gathering with each player trying to recruit an army of goblins made up of soldiers, heroes, magicians, and other classes – then swing it into action against the other players. Five clans of goblins are represented on the game cards, with goblins in one of three ranks. To build an army, a player must first recruit level I goblins, then build on those goblins with level II and finally level III. Those higher level goblins can be played only if a lower level goblin is of the same clan, and since goblins of the same clan have similar abilities or powers that mesh well, players tend to specialize in who they recruit to their ranks.

Each turn, a player can play a new goblin, use a goblin's power, draw cards, or pass. Many goblins have special powers that come into play when they're recruited, attacked, removed from play, placed with other goblins, and so on.

Once all players have passed, the player with the most powerful army wins the battle. Players keep cards in hand from one battle to the next, so laying out all your forces at once can leave you with little to do but get hit in later battles. The first player to win three battles wins the game.

While the game play in GOSU2 remains much the same as in GOSU, some changes make it a different game:


 The game no longer includes activation tokens, which were used to draw cards or activate a goblin's power.
 All text has been removed from the cards to make them (and the game as a whole) fully multilingual.
 Goblin abilities are now based on seven symbols, each with a basic and a MAX version.
 The game includes a new «link» ability.
 The goblin clans are structured differently.


Additionally, all cards are "cold foil" printed to make them shiny. Glitzy goblins – whodathunk?

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Trivia game about the nostalgic sixties. You can rediscover hippies, LSD, love beads and Vietnam. It is a simple trivia game that wasn't boxed.

According to an article in IN THESE TIMES SEPT 26-OCT 2. 1984, there is board with a Peace Sign Layout that includes limbos like the Free Clinic or the Establishment or hell, a.k.a. Vietnam. It is very difficult to get out of Vietnam, the vertical bar in the peace-symbol shaped route. Most of the cards are Trivia cards, but some of them are "Karma Cards" which can send you to one of these limbos for several turns
There is a a Roll and Move component.

Here is the strange thing, it seems to have been made by a Quaker person or company, yet it is not religious in any way. The catalogue inside the game suggests gifts about the Quaker movement. Gifts such as Quaker Tea, Quaker LPs, Quaker Checkers and Quaker Badges (sample slogan (I kid you not) "I skinnydip in the Ocean of Light".

A promotional game so it is a little basic.

Using dice players move along a track, entering hospital and then getting out of the hospital at the end of the track. The trick is to avoid picking up infections although this is completely down to luck. If you land on the bad squares, that is tough luck.

It has an educational feel to it. The maker is unknown to me, it could be, probably is, American, but I did track down a Stuart Pharmacueticals in Australia. Wherever the publisher resided, the message is clear. Avoid infection!

In Tokaido, each player is a traveler crossing the "East sea road", one of the most magnificent roads of Japan. While traveling, you will meet people, taste fine meals, collect beautiful items, discover great panoramas, and visit temples and wild places but at the end of the day, when everyone has arrived at the end of the road you'll have to be the most initiated traveler – which means that you'll have to be the one who discovered the most interesting and varied things.

The potential action spaces in Tokaido are laid out on a linear track, with players advancing down this track to take actions. The player who is currently last on the track takes a turn by advancing forward on the track to their desired action and taking that action, so players must choose whether to advance slowly in order to get more turns, or to travel more rapidly to beat other players to their desired action spaces.

The action spaces allow a variety of actions that will score in different, but roughly equal, ways. Some action spaces allow players to collect money, while others offer players a way to spend that money to acquire points. Other action spaces allow players to engage in various set collections that score points for assembling those sets. Some action spaces simply award players points for stopping on them, or give the player a randomly determined action from all of the other types.

All of the actions in Tokaido are very simple, and combined with a unique graphic design, Tokaido offers players a peaceful zen mood in its play.

item.description:
The Battle for Tannenbruck, West Germany 1985

Raid and Riposte Second Edition is an area-combat system of the Cold War in 1985 turning hot. The Soviets have invaded West Germany, and the ferocious battle for the crucial city of Tannenbruck, West Germany. The battle depicts the Soviet defense by the Soviet 1st Paratroop Regiment in its attempt to hold off repeated assaults by Bundeswehr and U.S. Army forces.

Raid and Riposte Second Edition is a quick-playing game with easy-to-learn rules and low counter density. The second edition has been made into a stand alone game (First Edition is still available in Line of Fire magazine issue 12. Raid and Riposte Second Edition has been updated to include a new map and counter design and updated game manual. This seven-turn game is played on a lush area movement map. Units represent companies, platoons, leaders, and ATGM and artillery batteries. The Soviets had the element of surprise, but NATO has plenty of armor and determination. Tannenbruck and its key river crossing are at stake. Infantry, tanks, helicopters, snipers, leaders and special-forces units are all involved. Here a unique look at a deadly “What-if” scenario, will the Soviets hold on until their reinforcements arrive or will the West Germans and Americans have the fortitude to retake the city?

Contents:
• Over 40+ .875" Die-cut Counters
• One 11”x17” Heavy Cardstock Map
• 16 Page Game Manual

item.description: The game consists of an "arena" (the game box with an insert) and lots of dice. The goal is to be the last player who still has dice. At the beginning, one die is in the arena. The active player throws another die into the arena. If both dice now show the same number, the player must take them out and end the turn. If not, the player can decide to throw in another die (possibly trying to overturn other dice) or end his/her turn. A die which shows the X face is removed from the game, as is any die which falls out of the arena. A player who holds no more dice is eliminated from the game. The last player who still has dice is the winner.

item.description:
Players in Illico compete in two teams that sit facing one another, the deck of "Illico" cards stacked between them (with a Cache card hiding the top card) and each with three "Joker" cards at their disposal. They choose a number from 1 to 12 to determine which line they'll look at on the cards.

At the start of a round, one team flips the sand timer while the other draws the top Illico card and looks at the appropriate line, which will show two things that can be referred to by the same word, such as "A direction and correct?" The team must answer with the word or phrase that describes both halves of the question – in this case "right". (The team holds up the card so that the opposing team can see the answer on the back of the card.) When the team does give the right answer, the other team draws a card and tries to answer the question. The process continues until time runs out, at which point the team not holding the card wins the round. While trying to guess an answer, a team can spend a Joker card to either learn the first letter of the answer or skip the card and draw a new one.

The first team to win three rounds wins the game!

item.description:
Sheepland is set on the beautiful island of the same name, where for centuries the population has taken care of sheep. While inexplicably working in the same field, two to four shepherds try to move sheep into the right areas to score points. During a turn, you must take three actions, chosen from these possibilities:


 Move your shepherd
 Move one sheep
 Buy one terrain tile


You must move your shepherd at least once during your turn, and you can't take the same action twice in a row without moving the shepherd between.

Six different terrain types are available, with five tiles of each type and increasing costs (from 0 to 4 dinars) on those tiles. When you buy a tile, you're not claiming land on the game board, but rather investing in that type of landscape as that's where you expect the sheep to end up grazing. At the end of the game, you score 1 point per tile of a terrain type for each sheep in a region of this type; you also score for coins still in hand.

The map on the game board shows regions separated by roads: three regions of each terrain type for a total of 18 regions. Numbered "rest stops" lie along the roads, with each rest stop between exactly two regions. Shepherds move from one rest stop to another, with the first movement being free and all others on the same turn costing 1 coin. When you buy a terrain, you can purchase the top tile of either of the two terrain types next to your shepherd. When you move a sheep, you move one sheep from a region adjacent to your shepherd to the other region adjacent to that piece, i.e., you lead the sheep across the road to a greener pastures – well, greener for you, if all goes well.

Each time you move the shepherd, you place a fence in the rest stop from which it started moving, making that location off-limits for the rest of the game. During the game some regions become inaccessible, and if they are full of sheep, naturally there's a rush for the tiles. The lone black sheep in the game, which is worth two points, serves as a semi-random element, possibly moving to an adjacent region each turn while still being movable by shepherds as long as it's not fenced in.

After twenty fences have been placed, you end the round so that all players have the same number of turns, then you count up the points.

item.description:
Each card has a picture of the TV series The Blondes.

Each player has a hair color chosen at the beginning of the game and they sit around the table in that order from the darkest to the lightest hair color (Brown, Chestnut, Auburn, Red, Blonde who must wear the included blonde wig). The goal of the game is collect the most points. The one that has the least points at the end of the game is the Blonde.

The cards are numbered from 1 to 10.
On their turn a player may either:
a) play a (better) card or combination (pair, 3/4/5 of a kind) than the previous player
b) pass
When all players have passed, one who has played the highest card or combination opens the next turn by playing new card or combination of their choice.
The player who got rid of all his cards first wins the round and becomes a Brown for the next round pushing the others one rank down.
